Both viral effect and immune-mediated mechanism are involved in the pathogenesis of severe acute respiratory syndrome-associated coronavirus (SARS-CoV) infection. In this study, we showed that in SARS patient sera there were autoantibodies (autoAbs) that reacted with A549 cells, the type-2 pneumocytes, and that these autoAbs were mainly IgG.

In addition, abnormal immune responses to SARS-CoV infection, such as the unbalance of immune cells and the production and dysregulation of cytokines and chemokines, may also underlie the pathogenesis of disease

The onset of autoimmunity has been related to viral infections. An influenza viral infection-induced autoimmune disease called Goodpasture's syndrome shows the existence of autoantibodies (autoAbs) against the alveolar and glomerular basement membrane [19–21], but there is no report regarding SARS-CoV-induced autoAb production.
